title: It is what it is?
text:
If that's what you think, if you believe you are hardwired and have no choices or your "brain" is somehow separate from yourself - and feel stuck - read on.

American born, European trained clinical/analytical psychologist* specializing in questions of masculine/feminine identity, intimacy/sensuality/trust, sexual dysfunction including impotence/frigidity and compulsive behaviors (e.g.sexual addiction), couples therapy, depression and substance use and abuse. 

Why a European perspective? What's different? Basically, Psychology has two parents: Philosophy in Europe, Education in America. The difference is essential. The former focuses on the "why, believing that no solution can be effective without understanding its' origins. The latter dismisses as relatively unimportant the "why," focusing on the what, and targeting a solution through more superficial behavior modification and pharmaceutical support. The implications and consequences are enormous for if one chooses the "shortcut," no meaningful foundation for change has been established. Depending on whether or not one wants to chart one's own course into the future or simply adapt to circumstances that has been defined by others, the choice is clear. To weather the inevitable storms, one needs strong, deep roots. Some general questions too often ignored or dismissed as "too difficult" and therefore not worthy of reflection:

- if I have a "type," are there understandable reasons?
- if my relationships always seem to follow the same course, do I somehow play a role?
- am I really "hard-wired" like this?
- are gender stereotypes immutable or are they invoked only to explain what we don't want to know?
- am I perhaps selling myself short by defining myself principally by my sexual preferences
- can sex possibly be a surrogate for other things?
- what is the role of sex in my emotional life? Or have I separated the two?
- why does random sex "appear" more "hot" and "fun" than sex with\a committed partner?
- am I afraid of true vulnerability and intimacy? Can I truly trust?
- is it normal that I have grown bored with my sexual partner? Does it have to be that way?
- is the past really in the past or I simply don't see it anymore?

Offering those ready to face the real questions driv0ing their lives in a direction incompatible with their objectives, an opportunity to explore and discover the deeper "why's" of their behavior and the "how's" of changing it where necessary. 

True to the principal that only what we pay for ourselves is truly worth something ("skin in the game"), no involvement of health insurance will be applicable. However, given the importance of this work, cost will be discussed and adapted to suit the abilities of those consulting.

Reply in confidence for an initial discussion.

Website: www.analyticalpsychologynyc.com
Yelp: analyticalpsychology
Tumblr: Wills Poems For Living
Amazon.com: Mr. Hide's Progress


*Due to lack of equivalence, not recognized in New York State

title: Control - How Much or Too Much?
text:
If you have questions like 

What is the true role of sex in a relationship?
What's the role of sensuality, intimacy and desire?
What is the meaning of loss of desire and flight into fantasy?
Insecurity - the real enemy?
What is sex really? A physical need? A language for expressing one's emotions? 
What is the role of fantasy and porn? Has the latter rendered emotion and sex incompatible?
Is Monogamy a worthwhile ideal? Am I truly capable of it or does the idea frighten me?
What's the real difference between sex and making love?

American born, European trained clinical/analytical psychologist* specializing in issues of masculine/feminine identity, intimacy/sensuality/trust, sexual dysfunction including impotence/frigidity and compulsive behaviors (e.g.sexual addiction), couples therapy, depression and substance use and abuse. 

Why a European perspective? What's different? Basically, Psychology has two parents: Philosophy in Europe, Education in America. The difference is essential. The former focuses on the "why, believing that no solution can be effective without understanding its' origins. The latter dismisses as relatively unimportant the why", focusing on the what, and targeting a solution through more superficial behavior modification and pharmaceutical support. The implications and consequences are enormous for if one chooses the "shortcut," no meaningful foundation for change has been established. Depending on whether or not one wants to chart one's own course into the future or simply adapt to circumstances that are most often beyond one's control, the choice is clear. To weather the inevitable storms, one needs strong roots. Some general questions too often ignored or dismissed as "too difficult" and therefore not worthy of reflection

Offering those ready to face the real questions driving their lives in a direction incompatible with their objectives, an opportunity to explore and discover the deeper "why's" of their behavior and the "how's" of changing it where necessary. 

True to the principal that only what we pay for ourselves is truly worth something ("skin in the game"), no involvement of health insurance will be applicable. However, given the importance of this work, cost will be discussed and adapted to suit the abilities of those consulting.

Reply in confidence for an initial discussion.

Website: www.analyticalpsychologynyc.com
Yelp: analyticalpsychologynyc
Amazon: Mr. Hide's Progress


*Due to lack of equivalence, not recognized in New York State

title: Changing Course
text:
If you have questions like 

What is the true role of sex in a relationship?
What's the role of sensuality, intimacy and desire?
What is the meaning of loss of desire and flight into fantasy?
Insecurity - the real enemy?
What is sex really? A physical need? A language for expressing one's emotions? 
What is the role of fantasy and porn? Has the latter rendered emotion and sex incompatible?
Is Monogamy a worthwhile ideal? Am I truly capable of it or does the idea frighten me?
What's the real difference between sex and making love?

American born, European trained clinical/analytical psychologist* specializing in issues of masculine/feminine identity, intimacy/sensuality/trust, sexual dysfunction including impotence/frigidity and compulsive behaviors (e.g.sexual addiction), couples therapy, depression and substance use and abuse. 

Why a European perspective? What's different? Basically, Psychology has two parents: Philosophy in Europe, Education in America. The difference is essential. The former focuses on the "why, believing that no solution can be effective without understanding its' origins. The latter dismisses as relatively unimportant the why", focusing on the what, and targeting a solution through more superficial behavior modification and pharmaceutical support. The implications and consequences are enormous for if one chooses the "shortcut," no meaningful foundation for change has been established. Depending on whether or not one wants to chart one's own course into the future or simply adapt to circumstances that are most often beyond one's control, the choice is clear. To weather the inevitable storms, one needs strong roots. Some general questions too often ignored or dismissed as "too difficult" and therefore not worthy of reflection

Offering those ready to face the real questions driving their lives in a direction incompatible with their objectives, an opportunity to explore and discover the deeper "why's" of their behavior and the "how's" of changing it where necessary. 

True to the principal that only what we pay for ourselves is truly worth something ("skin in the game"), no involvement of health insurance will be applicable. However, given the importance of this work, cost will be discussed and adapted to suit the abilities of those consulting.

Reply in confidence for an initial discussion.

Website: www.analyticalpsychologynyc.com
Yelp: analyticalpsychologynyc
Amazon: Mr. Hide's Progress


*Due to lack of equivalence, not recognized in New York State

title: HIV: Support Group for Men
text:
HIV Positive and looking for advice and support?

Whether you're newly diagnosed or coming to terms with your status, all call benefit and learn from each other in this optimistic group environment. While being positive is no longer considered a death sentence, there are many challenges that we face. Meet others coping with issues of:

-Stigma
-Depression and anxiety
-Medical care
-Understanding test results
-Medication
-Dating and relationships
-Disclosing your status to others
-Work or State Benefits

Come join us for an informal, non-threatening group chat where we can safely and discreetly discuss challenges and accomplishments of those of us living with HIV. Meetings are held every other week from 7-8:30pm in a discreet apartment -conveniently located in Chelsea. Unfortunately, stigma is a real issue which those of us face while living with HIV so your information or identity will not be shared. 

For more information go directly to our Meetup group's page (the URL is photo shown).
